ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course. The material was very interesting, and extremely applicable for anyone planning to continue work in the sciences via lab research, medicine, etc.
Yes, wonderful class and a great way to see how bio concepts are applied to modern technology and modern problems in the world. These kinds ofclasses are the reason I'm a bio major!

Covers a lot of interesting material in the realm of biotechnology. In general, chooses to cover more topics rather than flesh out a topic in more depth, so in that sense it's a survey course. I'd still recommend it.
Don't take this. It's a horrible survey class.

Really solid course. A great exposure to a lot of topics on the frontiers of biotechnology, the workload is pretty light, and I learned a lot. I don't remember what the listed prereqs are, but you're probably fine if you have even a basic understanding of genetics (I had no real bio background and felt able to kee up).
Great class, interesting material. Not all too difficult.

Having 4 different lecturers made the course a bit confusing, particularly since there wasn't a great deal of continuity between the lecturers. Aside from that though, the course was pretty interesting and served as a good survey course of what biotechnology's been up to lately. The non-cumulative exams are also a huge plus (this includes the final, which was just another hour exam that you've got three hours to take).
